category.term: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
category.label: Misc

content.div:
This week, the Dose.ca team put four face washes to the test. Find out which ones lived up to their claims and which ones fell short.



Body Shop Natrulift (Available at The Body Shop. Suggested retail price: $14.00)

“The Body Shop Natrulift worked just fine – but that’s the highest praise I can give it. It cleaned my face perfectly well, but it didn’t particularly stand out to me. I didn’t notice the ‘velvety-looking complexion’ the product promised, but there weren’t any real downsides, either; the Natrulift worked like a regular facial wash should. But hey, it smelled great! If you’re not looking for anything fancy, this is the one for you. Rating: 4/5” – Kat Angus, TV editor, Dose.ca

“Creamy to the point of resembling a body butter lotion and lightly scented with a nutty fragrance coupled with pomegrante, the Natrulift was my favourite of the four tested products in terms of the sheer experience. Post-shower, however, I found it moisturized my skin to a fault. After patting my face dry, my skin was soft, but also just a touch oily -- not to the point of risking a brea-out, but it definitely left me desperate for an extra swoop of the powder brush. Rating: 4/5” –Leah Collins, music editor, Dose.ca

“I loved the Natrulift. It smelled so good I could almost eat it -- which, if you know me, pretty much makes anything a winner in my books. This cleanser was super thick which made it feel luxurious and for $14, it’s a steal. It may not have given me a ‘velvety-looking complexion’ but for a face wash, it did its job. It left me feeling cleansed and moisturized (and slightly hungry). Rating: 4/5." –Miranda Furtado, style editor, Dose.ca

“I’m currently using a ‘lifting moisturizer,’ so I was half expecting to start Benjamin Button-ing once I added the Natrulift face wash. No such luck. Though I didn’t see any evidence that it ‘minimized the signs of aging,’ I loved the texture. It was super thick like a lotion, but it still washed off easily. My only complaint: I found the scent overwhelming. It would have been lovely at any other time of the day, but it was a little hard to take at 6:30 a.m. It turns out that I don’t want to be assaulted with a fruity chocolate smell when I first wake up. Who knew? Rating: 3/5” – Jen McDonnell, managing editor, Dose.ca


L'Oreal Skin Genesis Pore Minimizing Gel Cleanser (Available at drugstores. Suggested retail price: $12.99)

“If you're looking for an all-purpose facial cleanser -- something you can use both in the morning, and when sloughing off your make-up at night -- this product was the best of the four. It's fluid, quick-to-lather, and up to the task of erasing my make-up at the end of the day. (Plus, its pump-bottle packaging has guaranteed it some real estate on my shower shelf.) Although it made my complexion its freshest, it was also the only product of the four that left my skin thirsty for moisturizer. It's not overly drying, but was certainly the most soapy of the bunch. Rating: 4/5” –LC

“This one also hit a high note with me. The fact that it was a pump instead of a squeeze bottle was a bonus. I liked the fact that the scent was refreshing, not overbearing. Because it wasn't as thick as the other products, it was the easiest to lather. As for being a ‘pore minimizer,’ I can't say that I’m concerned with the size of my pores to begin with, so I chose to disregard that claim. Rating: 3.5/5" - MF

“You’re supposed to use this face wash in conjunction with all of the other Skin Genesis products – which I bought and are now buried in my makeup drawer somewhere. I quickly abandoned the system after I realized how many steps it required (I need to apply a serum before my moisturizer? No, thanks!), so I can’t speak to how the face wash works in combination with the rest of the line. I’m not sure if it reduced the size of my pores (is that something we’re actually supposed to be worried about?), but this product is a great everyday cleanser. Its gel texture felt light on my skin, the smell was delicate and not overpowering and, most impressively, it easily removed all of my makeup – including my mascara. I’m definitely going to add this to my nighttime routine. Rating: 4/5” – JM


Weleda Gentle Cleansing Milk (Available at weleda.ca, Whole Foods and select health food stores. Suggested retail price $19.00)

“This was my least favourite of all three facial cleansers. After wiping off the Cleansing Milk with a damp cotton pad (as per the instructions), my skin felt like it still had goop on it, a feeling that didn’t go away until I got home and night and washed my face with actual soap. If that’s what it feels like to have a “healthy balance in your skin,” I’ll pass. Rating: 0/5” -- KA

“The refreshing, lavender scent and two-step application process makes for a relaxing morning ritual. Me, I don’t need no herbal-scented ritual. I just want to wash my face -- and as quickly as possible, if I can help it. In terms of results, my face felt no cleaner or calmed than from using any of the other products -- and I had to use a lot less of the others in order to get ready for the day. (Think one drop vs. at least four dollops of the cleansing milk, the most expensive product on this list, no less.) Rating: 3/5” –LC

“I cannot say that I'm a fan of the Weleda Cleansing Milk. I had difficulty putting on and an even tougher time taking it off. After using a damp cotton pad -- or should I say five cotton pads -- I felt like my face was still covered in goop. Rating 2/5” -- MF

“It took me a while to figure out the best way to apply and remove this one (I finally had success when I applied it with my fingers and removed it with a dry cotton pad), but it ended up being my favourite of the bunch. It smelled lovely, left my skin velvety soft and reminded me of something that they’d use at the spa. I didn’t look at any of the prices before we started testing, but this product’s texture, scent and packaging (in comes in a blue glass bottle) made me certain it was the most expensive of the bunch. Rating: 4/5” – JM


Olay Shine Control Lathering Cleanser (Available at drugstores. Suggested retail price: $12.99)

“When Olay says this controls shine, they’re not lying. My face usually starts getting shiny around mid-afternoon, but after using the Shine Control, I didn’t have a problem with it all day. My problem? With my combination skin, the area around my nose gets flaky very easily, and the Olay only exacerbated this issue; my face was shine-free, but the skin around my nose was even dryer than usual. My only recourse was to use more moisturizer, which had the unfortunate effect of cancelling out most of Olay’s shine-preventing effect. However, if your skin, overall, is fairly oily, the Olay Shine Control is a definite must-have. Rating: 3/5” -- KAM

“It claims to cleanse like a mud mask. No wonder: this product is as thick as one. (Expect to use a little extra oomph getting this stuff/the bottle.) My pores are still getting back to me on whether they're feeling cleaner than clean, but overall, I found it safe to use on my sensitive skin, and enjoyed starting the day with its fresh, soap-y scent. Rating: 3.5/5” –LC

“I found the Olay Shine Control the most difficult to use. They weren't kidding when they compared it to a mask. After applying the clay-like product to my face cloth, I found it very difficult to lather. After a few days of trial and error, I determined the perfect amount of product to use, and then I became a fan. Rating 3.5/5” – MF

“This one felt more like a mask than a daily cleanser. It’s so thick that I’d be hesitant to use it everyday, but it certainly delivered on its promise of down-to-the-pores surface cleansing. In fact, my face almost felt squeaky clean after using it, which is probably not a good thing. Feeling stripped of all of my natural oils, I just ended up using more moisturizer than usual. Rating: 2/5” –JM
